person_181.name: Hippocrates
person_181.description: Green physician of the classical period.

person_182.name: Democritus
person_182.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

person_035.name: Homer
person_035.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

person_939.name: Aristides
person_939.description: An Athenian statesman remembered for his generalship in the Persian War.

person_175.name: Miltiades
person_175.description: Greek Athenian citizen known mostly for his role in the Battle of Marathon.

person_177.name: Leonidas
person_177.description: King of the Greek city-state of Sparta.

person_140.name: Socrates
person_140.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

person_490.name: Xenophon
person_490.description: A Greek military leader, historian and philosopher, who was a student of Socrates. He recorded some of Socrates' philosophy. He is mainly remembered for his book Anabasis.

person_810.name: Alexander III
person_810.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_340.name: Atheneus
person_340.description: Of Naucratis was a Greek rhetorician and grammarian.

person_136.name: Almanon
person_136.description: The Anglicised form of Al-Ma'mun, the seventh Abbasid caliph who reigned from 813-833 CE - a patron of learning.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_873.name: Iran
place_873.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

place_1311.name: Baghdad
place_1311.description: the capital of Iraq and the second-largest city in the Arab world after Cairo
